sect1.title: ⪪ Configuration Files
sect1.para: The main ⪪ configuration file is /etc/smt.conf. You can set most of the options with the &yast; ⪪ Server module. Another important configuration file is /etc/smt.d/smt-cron.conf, which contains parameters for commands launched as ⪪ scheduled jobs.

sect2.title: /etc/smt.conf
sect2.para: The /etc/smt.conf file has several sections. The [NU] section contains the update credentials and URL. The [DB] section contains the configuration of the &mariadb; database for ⪪. The [LOCAL] section includes other configuration data. The [REPORT] section contains the configuration of ⪪ reports.

warning.title: Passwords in Clear Text
warning.para: The /etc/smt.conf file contains passwords in clear text. Its default permissions (640, root, wwwrun) make its content easily accessible with scripts running on the Apache server. Be careful with running other software on the ⪪ Apache server. The best policy is to use this server only for ⪪.

sect3.title: [NU] Section of /etc/smt.conf
sect3.para: The following options are available in the [NU] section:

listitem.para: URL of the update service. Usually it should contain the https://updates.suse.com/ URL.
URL of the update registration service. It is used by smt-sync. If this option is missing, the URL from /etc/SUSEConnect is used as a fallback.
NUUser should contain the user name for update service. For information about getting organization credentials, see . You can set this value with the ⪪ Server.
NUPass is the password for the user defined in NUUser. For information about getting organization credentials, see . You can set this value with the ⪪ Server.
ApiType is the type of service ⪪ uses; it can be either NCC for Novell Customer Center or SCC for &scc;. The only supported value for ⪪ 12 is SCC.

sect3.title: [DB] Section of /etc/smt.conf
sect3.para: The three options defined in the [DB] section are used for configuring the database for ⪪. Currently, only &mariadb; is supported by ⪪.

listitem.para: The first parameter of the DBI->connect Perl method used for connection to the &mariadb; database. The value should be in the form
where SMT is the name of the database and LOCALHOST is the host name of the database server.
The user for the database. The default value is smt.
The password for the database user. You can set the password with the &yast; ⪪ Server module.

sect3.title: [LOCAL] Section of /etc/smt.conf
sect3.para: The following options are available in the [LOCAL] section:

listitem.para: The base URL of the ⪪ server which is used to construct URLs of the repositories available on the server. This value should be set by &yast; automatically during installation. The format of this option should be: https://server.domain.tld/.

You can change the URL manually. For example, the administrator may choose to use the http:// scheme instead of https:// for performance reasons. Another reason may be using an alias (configured with CNAME in DNS) instead of the host name of the server. For example, http://smt.domain.tld/ instead of http://server1.domain.tld/.
E-mail address used for registration at the &scc;. The ⪪ administrator can set this value with the &yast; ⪪ Server module.
Determines the path to mirror to.
If the MirrorAll option is set to true, the smt-sync script will set all repositories that can be mirrored to be mirrored (DOMIRROR flag).
If the MirrorSRC option is set to true, source RPM packages are mirrored.

note.title: Default Value Changed with ⪪ 11 SP2
note.para: With ⪪ 11 SP2, the preset default value was changed to false. If you also want ⪪ to mirror source RPM packages on new installations, set MirrorSRC to true.

listitem.para: Specify a delay in seconds before the clients are registered at &scc;. The value is a random number between 0 and 450, generated by the &yast; ⪪ Server module. The purpose of this random delay is to prevent a high load on the &scc; server that would occur if all smt-register cron jobs connected at the same time.
Specify the path to the script that will be run before the smt-mirror script removes its lock.
Specify the path to the script that will be run after the smt-mirror script removes its lock.
If you do not want to use global proxy settings, specify the proxy to be used for HTTP connection here. Use the following form: http://PROXY.&exampledomain;:3128.

If the proxy settings are not configured in /etc/smt.conf, the global proxy settings configured in /etc/syconfig/proxy are used. You can configure the global proxy settings with the &yast; Proxy module.
If you do not want to use global proxy settings, specify the proxy to be used for HTTPS connection here. Use the form: https://PROXY.&exampledomain;:3128.

If the proxy settings are not configured in /etc/smt.conf, the global proxy settings configured in /etc/syconfig/proxy are used. You can configure the global proxy settings with the &yast; Proxy module.
If your proxy requires authentication, specify a user name and password here, using the USERNAME:PASSWORD format.

If the proxy settings are not configured in /etc/smt.conf, the global proxy settings configured in /etc/syconfig/proxy are used. You can configure the global proxy settings with the &yast; Proxy module.

tip.title: Global User Authentication Setting
tip.para: If you configure the global proxy settings with &yast;, manually copy /root/.curlrc to the home directory of the smt. Adjust the permissions with the following commands as &rootuser;:

listitem.para: Specify an authentication type to access the repository. There are three possible types:
none - no authentication is required. This is the default value.
lazy - only user name and password are checked. A valid user can access all repositories.
strict - checks also if the user has access to the repository.
Specify a user name of a Unix user under which all smt commands will run.
Specify the ID of the GPG key to sign modified repositories. The user specified under smtUser needs to have access to the key. If this option is not set, the modified repositories will be unsigned.

sect3.title: [REST] Section of /etc/smt.conf
sect3.para: The following options are available in the [REST] section:

listitem.para: If set to 1, turns administrative access to the ⪪ RESTService on. Default value is 0.
Specify the user name that the REST-Admin uses to log in. Default value is RESTroot.
Specify the password for the REST-Admin user. The option has no default value. An empty password is invalid.

sect3.title: [JOBQUEUE] Section of /etc/smt.conf
sect3.para: The following options are available in the [JOBQUEUE] section:

listitem.para: Specify the maximum age of finished non-persistent jobs in days. Default value is 8.

Specify a comma separated list of JobQueue status IDs that should be interpreted as successful. For more information about possible status IDs, see smt-job --help. Leaving this option empty is interpreted as default (1,4).

sect3.title: [REPORT] Section of /etc/smt.conf
sect3.para: The following options are available in the [REPORT] section:

listitem.para: A comma separated list of e-mail addresses to send ⪪ status reports to. You can set this list with the &yast; ⪪ Server module.
From field of report e-mails. If not set, the default root@HOSTNAME.DOMAINNAME will be used.
Relay mail server. If empty, e-mails are sent directly.
Port of the relay mail server set in mailServer.
User name for authentication to the mail server set in mailServer.
Password for authentication to the mail server set in mailServer.

example.title: smt.conf
example.screen:
[NU] NUUrl=https://updates.suse.com/ NURegUrl=https://scc.suse.com/connect NUUser = exampleuser NUPass = examplepassword ApiType = SCC
[DB] config = dbi:mysql:database=smt;host=localhost user = smt pass = smt
[LOCAL] # Default should be http://server.domain.top/ url = http://smt.example.com/ # This email address is used for registration at SCC nccEmail = exampleuser@example.com MirrorTo = /srv/www/htdocs MirrorAll = false MirrorSRC = false forwardRegistration = true rndRegister = 127 # The hook script that should be called before the smt-mirror script removes its lock mirror_preunlock_hook = # The hook script that should be called after the smt-mirror script removed its lock mirror_postunlock_hook = # specify proxy settings here, if you do not want to use the global proxy settings # If you leave these options empty the global options are used. # # specify which proxy you want to use for HTTP connection # in the form http://proxy.example.com:3128 HTTPProxy = # specify which proxy you want to use for HTTPS connection # in the form http://proxy.example.com:3128 HTTPSProxy = # specify username and password if your proxy requires authentication # in the form username:password ProxyUser = # # require authentication to access the repository? # Three possible authtypes can be configured here # 1) none : no authentication required (default) # 2) lazy : check only username and password. A valid user has access to all repositories # 3) strict : check also if this user has access to the repository. # requiredAuthType = none # # the smt commands should run with this unix user # smtUser = smt # # ID of the GPG key to be used to sign modified (filtered) repositories. # The key must be accessible by the user who runs SMT, i.e. the user specified # in the 'smtUser' configuration option. # # If empty, the modified repositories will be unsigned. # signingKeyID = # # This string is sent in HTTP requests as UserAgent. # If the key UserAgent does not exist, a default is used. # If UserAgent is empty, no UserAgent string is set. # #UserAgent= # Organization credentials for this SMT server. # These are currently only used to get list of all available repositories # from https://your.smt.url/repo/repoindex.xml # Note: if authenticated as a client machine instead of these mirrorUser, # the above URL returns only repositories relevant for that client. mirrorUser = mirrorPassword =
[REST] # Enable administrative access to the ⪪ RESTService by setting enableRESTAdminAccess=1 # default: 0 enableRESTAdminAccess = 0 # Define the username the REST-Admin uses for login # default: RESTroot RESTAdminUser = RESTroot # Define the password for the REST-Admin (note: empty password is invalid) # default: <empty> RESTAdminPassword =
[JOBQUEUE] # maximum age of finished (non-persistent) jobs in days # default: 8 maxFinishedJobAge = 8 # comma separated list of JobQueue status IDs that should be interpreted as successful # See smt-job --help for more information about possible Status IDs # Please note: An empty string will be interpreted as default (1,4). # default: 1,4 # useful: 1,4,6 jobStatusIsSuccess = 1,4
[REPORT] # comma separated list of eMail addresses where the status reports will be sent to reportEmail = exampleuser@example.com # from field of report mails - if empty it defaults to "root@<hostname>.<domainname>" reportEmailFrom = # relay mail server - leave empty if mail should be sent directly mailServer = mailServerPort = # mail server authentication - leave empty if not required mailServerUser = mailServerPassword =

sect2.title: /etc/smt.d/smt-cron.conf
sect2.para: The /etc/smt.d/smt-cron.conf configuration file contains options of the ⪪ commands launched as ⪪ scheduled jobs set with &yast; (see ). Cron is used to launch these scheduled jobs. The cron table is located in the /etc/cron.d/novell.com-smt file.

listitem.para: Contains parameters of the smt scc-sync command, if called as part of an ⪪ scheduled job via cron. The default value is "-L /var/log/smt/smt-sync.log --mail".
Contains parameters of the smt mirror command, if called as part of an ⪪ scheduled job via cron. The default value is "-L /var/log/smt/smt-mirror.log --mail" .
Contains parameters of the smt register command, if called as part of an ⪪ scheduled job via cron. The default value is "-r -L /var/log/smt/smt-register.log --mail" .
Contains parameters of the smt report command, if called as part of an ⪪ scheduled job via cron. The default value is "--mail --attach -L /var/log/smt/smt-report.log" .
Contains parameters for smt jobqueue cleanup, if called as a part of an ⪪ scheduled job via cron. The default value is "--mail -L /var/log/smt/smt-jobqueuecleanup.log".
